references: In this section, we first describe our hierarchical edge network system model (Sec.Â II-A) and formalize the ML task under consideration (Sec.Â II-B). Then, we develop our delay-aware federated learning procedure, DFL (Sec.Â II-C). A list of acronyms and symbols used is provided in TableÂ I andÂ II.

references: We consider ML model learning over the hierarchical network architecture depicted in Fig.Â

. The network consists of three layers of nodes. At the top of the hierarchy,
a main server (e.g., a cloud server) is in charge of global model aggregations. In the middle of the hierarchy, there are
edge servers (e.g., coexisting with cellular base stations), collected via the set
, which act as local model aggregators. Finally, at the bottom of the hierarchy, there are
edge devices represented via the set

in charge of local model training.
The edge devices are organized into subnets (subnetworks), with a one-to-one mapping between the subnets and the edge servers, providing them uplink/downlink connectivity. In particular,
the devices
are partitioned into
This model is capable of being adapted to time-varying topologies, for instance, mobile devices switching subnet. However, we omit this for notational simplicity.
